edu.rit.io

Class OutStream

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.io.OutStream

  • public class OutStream
extends Object
    Class OutStream provides an object that writes primitive data types, strings, objects, and arrays in binary form to an underlying output stream. The resulting byte stream can be read using class InStream as described in more detail in the individual methods.

    The methods for writing integer types and strings write a variable number of bytes, as described in more detail in the individual methods. This can save space in the byte stream if small integer values are written more frequently than large integer values.

    Several methods for writing objects are provided:

    • writeFields() writes just the fields of a Streamable object. Use this method when the reader knows the class of the object ahead of time and has already created an instance of that class.

    • writeObject() writes both the class name and the fields of a Streamable or Serializable object. Use this method when the reader does not know the class of the object ahead of time.

    • writeReference() writes the class name and the fields of a Streamable or Serializable object, and also keeps a reference to the object. If the same object is passed to writeReference() again, just a reference to the previous object is written. Use this method when the reader needs to end up with multiple references to the same object.

    Classes OutStream and InStream provide a lightweight object serialization capability—one that generates fewer bytes than Java Object Serialization in package java.io. However, the programmer is responsible for writing all the serialization and deserialization code in each class that implements interface Streamable.

    To support interoperability with classes designed to work with Java Object Serialization, writeObject() and writeReference() will work both on Streamable objects and on Serializable objects. In the latter case, the object is converted to a byte array using Java Object Serialization, and the byte array is written.

    Methods for writing arrays of primitive types, strings, and objects are provided. Methods for writing multidimensional arrays are not provided; you can write a multidimensional array by writing a series of single-dimensional arrays.

    Class OutStream includes buffering. All bytes written are stored in an internal buffer. The buffer is flushed to the underlying output stream when the buffer fills up, the flush() method is called, or the close() method is called.

    Note: Class OutStream is not multiple thread safe.

      • OutStream

        public OutStream(OutputStream out)
        Construct a new out stream. The internal buffer size is the default (8192 bytes).
        Parameters:
        out - Underlying output stream.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if out is null.

      • OutStream

        public OutStream(OutputStream out,
         int size)
        Construct a new out stream with the given internal buffer size.
        Parameters:
        out - Underlying output stream.
        size - Internal buffer size ≥ 1 (bytes).
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if out is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if size < 1.

    • Method Detail

      • writeBoolean

        public void writeBoolean(boolean v)
                  throws IOException
        Write the given Boolean value to this out stream. One byte is written, either 0 (if v is false) or 1 (if v is true).

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readBoolean().

        Parameters:
        v - Boolean value.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readByte().

        Parameters:

        Throws:

      • writeShort

        public void writeShort(short v)
                throws IOException
        Write the given short value to this out stream. From one to three bytes are written, depending on the value; smaller absolute values require fewer bytes.

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readShort().

        Parameters:
        v - Short value.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

        public void writeDouble(double v)
                 throws IOException
        Write the given double value to this out stream. Eight bytes are written.

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readDouble().

        Parameters:
        v - Double value.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeString

        public void writeString(String v)
                 throws IOException
        Write the given string value to this out stream. The length of the string is written using writeInt(), then each character of the string is written using writeChar(). If v is null, then a length of −1 is written.

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readString().

        Parameters:
        v - String value, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeFields

        public void writeFields(Streamable v)
                 throws IOException
        Write the given object's fields to this out stream. The fields are written by calling v.writeOut(). v must not be null.

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readFields().

        Parameters:
        v - Object.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is null.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeObject

        public void writeObject(Object v)
                 throws IOException
        Write the given object to this out stream. If v is null, a 0 byte is written. Otherwise, a nonzero index designating the object's class is written using writeUnsignedInt(); if this is the first occurrence of the class, the class name is written using writeString(); and either (a) for a streamable object, the object's fields are written by calling writeFields(), or (b) for a serializable object, the object is converted to a byte array using Java Object Serialization and the byte array is written.

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readObject().

        Note: If the same object is written multiple times using writeObject(), the reader will end up with multiple different objects (that are copies of each other). If the reader needs to end up with multiple references to the same object, use writeReference().

        Parameters:
        v - Object, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeReference

        public void writeReference(Object v)
                    throws IOException
        Write a reference to the given object to this out stream. If v is null, a 0 byte is written. Otherwise, a nonzero index designating the object reference is written using writeUnsignedInt(); if this is the first occurrence of the object, the object is written using writeObject(), and the object is saved in a cache so that later calls to writeReference() will write just the reference index. To clear the cache, call clearCache().

        To read the value, the reader must call InStream.readReference().

        Note: If the same object is written multiple times using writeReference(), the reader will end up with multiple references to the same object. If the reader needs to end up with multiple different objects (that are copies of each other), use writeObject().

        Parameters:
        v - Object, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • clearCache

        public void clearCache()
        Clear the cache of objects that have been written using writeReference(). Afterwards, this out stream will act as though no objects had been previously written using writeReference().

        The reader must call InStream.clearCache() at the same point as the writer called clearCache().

      • writeBooleanArray

        public void writeBooleanArray(boolean[] v)
                       throws IOException
        Write the given Boolean array to this out stream. The length of the array is written using writeInt(), then each element of the array is written using writeBoolean(). If v is null, then a length of −1 is written.

        To read the array, the reader must call InStream.readBooleanArray(), InStream.readBooleanArray(boolean[]), or InStream.readBooleanArray(boolean[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Boolean array, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeBooleanArray

        public void writeBooleanArray(boolean[] v,
                     int off,
                     int len)
                       throws IOException
        Write a portion of the given Boolean array to this out stream. The length of the portion is written using writeInt(), then each element of the portion is written using writeBoolean(). If v is null, then a length of −1 is written.

        To read the array, the reader must call InStream.readBooleanArray(), InStream.readBooleanArray(boolean[]), or InStream.readBooleanArray(boolean[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Boolean array, or null.
        off - Index of first element to write.
        len - Number of elements to write.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is non-null and off < 0, len < 0, or off+len > v.length.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

        len - Number of elements to write.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is non-null and off < 0, len < 0, or off+len > v.length.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeUnsignedLongArray

        public void writeUnsignedLongArray(long[] v)
                            throws IOException
        Write the given unsigned long array to this out stream. The length of the array is written using writeInt(), then each element of the array is written using writeUnsignedLong(). If v is null, then a length of −1 is written.

        To read the array, the reader must call InStream.readUnsignedLongArray(), InStream.readUnsignedLongArray(long[]), or InStream.readUnsignedLongArray(long[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Unsigned long array, or null.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeUnsignedLongArray

        public void writeUnsignedLongArray(long[] v,
                          int off,
                          int len)
                            throws IOException
        Write a portion of the given unsigned long array to this out stream. The length of the portion is written using writeInt(), then each element of the portion is written using writeUnsignedLong(). If v is null, then a length of −1 is written.

        To read the array, the reader must call InStream.readUnsignedLongArray(), InStream.readUnsignedLongArray(long[]), or InStream.readUnsignedLongArray(long[],int,int).

        Parameters:
        v - Unsigned long array, or null.
        off - Index of first element to write.
        len - Number of elements to write.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if v is non-null and off < 0, len < 0, or off+len > v.length.
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • writeObjectArray

        public void writeObjectArray(Object[] v)
                      throws IOException
        Write the given object array to this out stream. The length of the array is written using writeInt(), the array element class is written, then each element of the array is written using writeObject(). If v is null, then a length of −1 is written.

        To read the array, the reader must call InStream.readObjectArray(), InStream.readObjectArray(Object[]), or InStream.readObjectArray(Object[],int,int).

      • flush

        public void flush()
           throws IOException
        Flush this out stream to the underlying output stream. Any buffered bytes are written to the underlying output stream, and the underlying output stream is flushed.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.

      • close

        public void close()
           throws IOException
        Close this out stream. Any buffered bytes are written to the underlying output stream, and the underlying output stream is flushed and closed.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown if an I/O error occurred.
